Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2015 02:56AM - edited Feb 19, 2015 02:57AM by alicki Hi, I'm going to help out on this one. If you want to be sure, contact the London Breast Institute, London, ask for professor Mokbel, he definitely knows what IBC is, although I agree with Kicks, there can  be many possibilities. It's private, you'll end up paying about 500 pounds but they will do the biopsy too (another 500 pounds). THinking I had IBC drove me to the point of sheer madness, it ruined my health for 18 months, I lost 20 kilos, had multiple headaches (which I convinced myself were brain mets!) and drove myself MAD.  Health anxiety can ruin your life and in fact I think anxiety can do more damage than the cancer itself. So from one person suffering from health anxiety to another, be very careful not to convince yourself you have IBC before getting an answer. Dermatologist sounds like a good idea! Take care, Alicki   PS: Kicks if you are reading this, the headaches went away, thanks for your support, I really appreciated it.

Someone said to me that its easy to get scans here, yes it is but it's more difficult to get competent breast surgeons because we only have ob/gyn and few breast surgeons in the French speaking part of Switzerland . THis radiologist writes the European guidelines for breast care, so I think he does know what he is talking about. I have now had three top Breast surgeons and radiologists tell me that my lymph nodes are ok, the one in Switzerland who authorised the MRI said that sometimes, they do take a while to go back down after an inflammatory process. Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2014 12:54AM alicki wrote: Hello, I think I should explain myself. Last July, I woke up to extremely painful breasts. Shortly followed by an outburst of fatty lymph nodes (which I still have), redness, thickened skin and one breast growing a bit bigger than the other. The local hospital put me under surveillance for IBC, not quite sure if I had cancer or an episode of mastitis (not lactating). They never gave me a diagnosis and left me lingering, with comments such as 'well if it's IBC, it will show up sooner or later'.  I was alone. So I went to see various specialists (abroad and the very few here) and all excluded IBC (inflammatory breast cancer) without telling me what had happened to me. In this process, I lost 18 kilos, why I don't know. I finally decided to get a breast reduction as a way to get some answers because even MRIs were not giving answers. The biopsies was just saying  that I had inflammation That's when I found out that I had Fibrocystic breasts and hyperplasia of the skin. The pathologist who I know and trust 100%, told me that I would need to be checked twice a year.  I  hope this explains why I am anxious. I am working on being less anxious, but all this fibrocystic breast issue is totally new to me. The only thing that I'm happy about is that I know now what explained the happenings of my left breast. I had a hysterectomy in 2010 (internal endometriosis) and at that time, I did not have fibrocystic breasts (exams done). I don't have dense tissue but fatty tissue so at least I don't have that issue. THank you for replying to my query and I apologize if I come across as a little mad. Switzerland is a small country and there are very few Breast surgeons. Here OB/GNY usually do breast operations, because there's no specific breast surgeon training, OB/GNY train for 'top' and 'bottom' and then some of them specialize in 'top' or 'bottom', mostly 'bottom' if I am making any sense, lol! There are a good few, but few, and even fewer in the French speaking part of Switzerland where I live So, I guess that's why I'm a little cranky (and I avoid Dr google because I would go mad). That's for the information you have provided me with. alicki

Posts.Content: May 13, 2014 01:12AM alicki wrote: Hello Melissa and Wolfslady,  First Wolfslady, thanks for your testimony. I think one needs to find the right balance between one's anxiety and concern about their breast health. I just found out that I have a massive area of fat necrosis (after breast reduction), and am trying not to get anxious over it, (it's a b9 condition). However, for my peace of mind, am asking a 2nd radiologist to check the MRI images and am going to talk to my PS. Funny, it's the other breast (right one this time!) Melissa: I would say that you are right. Anxiety stemmed from not feeling that I could trust the doctors I was seeing. And it drove me to a breast reduction to get the answers I needed, (they wouldn't do a core biospy at the time). As you know that showed FB and ductal hyperplasia without atypia, and at last I got an indication as to WHY I was having inflammation and so on. In the process, I lost 20 kilos in six months which made the anxiety shoot through the roof and all of a sudden, I started growing cysts in weird areas. I then started seeking help and my doc put me on medical leave the time to deal with the anxiety (back to work in June). Meantime, more inflammation on right breast, and MRI was ordered and it happens I have an area of 9cm *3cm of fat necrosis and lots of scar tissue that is still inflammed. (GRRH). So it's not all an anxiety problem but anxiety I would say caused breast problems. And what was really bad for me was that I had endless waiting between biopsies and was thrown to the ground by one doc who said to me: 'you know, in some cases, we've only found out it was IBC, after a few months'. That really made me freak out! I rarely come here now and try and stay off any BC related pages (apart of my therapy). Today, I just happened to come. I feel vulnerable whilst I am usually quite a strong and determined person.  Anxiety can destroy a life and I'm lucky because as far as I know, I don't have BC. I have learnt one thing: you can't diagnose yourself. Find docs you can trust and then trust them. No, they are not Gods, but nothing is 100%.  I now have the surveillance that I wished for and the reassurance of knowing that if ever anything nasty comes up one day, it (hopefully) will be caught early. That's all I am asking for. Thanks for reading my thoughts  Alicki

Posts.Content: alicki wrote: hello, I had a breast reduction and was initially told that it doesn't modify the risk of getting cancer. Yesterday I met with a plastic breast oncologist surgeon (he does both: oncology and breast plastics).  He said that yes, in case of FB, even without atypia you do reduce your risks because you re taking off some of the tissue that could become cancerous. I noticed a few years ago that someone on this site had mentioned the same thing. I wonder if any research has been done in the US on this. I went from cup E to C.  And no (I hope Melissa is reading me), you don't need a BMX for your breasts if they are without atypia. Right there gal :-) FB is no longer known as a disease but a condition and lymphatic massage greatly helps the circulation in the breasts to get better.  Anyways, I have at last found two docs and a radiologist I can trust. I wanted to get a mammo done but as I had to have an emergency procedure here in Switzerland they said 'no' and the radiologist wasn't too happy about the low quality resolution of the mammography. I have now learnt that in addition to all our other concerns, we need to make sure that the digital mammograms being used by our radiologists are of high resolution. Seriously?  European docs are allergic to the idea of mammographies more than one a year which explains why we are being sent for ultrasounds and MRIs all the time. They fear that radiation will induce cancers  Lastly, from another doc here, I found out that the 3D can be used with only one dose of radiation. In case of doubt, they will do an MRI. They are MRI mad here I think.  Don't know if any of this info can be helpful but wanted to post anyway Best, Alicki Log in to post a reply

Sleep apnea causes brain damage by lack of oxygen at night when you stop breathing I was so anxious that I believed that I had mets to brain when in fact once the sleep apnea was discovered and found and treated, things went back to normal . I can't tell u if its cancer or not but just make sure you have peace of mind. I nearly ruined my life over this, I lost my job, friends, home and nearly my mind Now I get things checked and make sure I have docs I can trust. Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2015 11:35AM - edited Dec 29, 2015 01:15PM by alicki Hello, Looks Like we re "health sisters" -2010: hysterectomy for internal endometriosis . It took them 6 months to find it -2013-2014: IBC scare (took 12 months to completely clear me in my home country but international expert had cleared me in 2 months - however I had ongoing headache problems and white matter in scans and completely lost it! 2012: H Pylori: which was well dealt with and found quickly The IBC scare gave me severe post traumatic stress. I went to the extreme of reducing my breasts to get answers which created a whole lot of other problems. I was convinced I would be dead by Dec 2015. Finally I had lymphatic congestion and sleep apnea but the while uncertainty gave me panic attacks I didn't even know existed - I beg of you don't go there. I went crazy because the medical follow up was so bad where I live to the point that my GP wrote a letter of complaint and I ve now got a specialist I need to have Anxiety gets me too, but I have learnt that knowledge is power and learnt to advocate and to get good docs I can trust. When it gets too bad, I do some meditation and breathing techniques and if it gets too bad I grab an Ativan. My experience is this and from what I'm reading so is yours. It may quack like a duck, look like a duck but that doesn't mean it's a duck!! I ll be on the boards until end of Jan so don't hesitate if you re feeling too bad Best Alicki PS: I use an apple app for meditation - works well. It s called "relax", it s for breathing to

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2014 01:24PM - edited Mar 5, 2014 01:26PM by alicki Hello,  I'm going to reply because my situation is quite like yours. Partial Hysterectomy in 2010 (still have ovaries), Breast reduction in 2013, further to inflammation and pain (reduction material showed fibrocystic breasts, left is worse than right too :-). There was a cancer scare because I thought it could have been IBC and docs were watching it for that but no cancer was found.  I'm having my breasts checked twice a year, once with 3D mammogram  (apparently 20-25% better) + ultrasound and once with MRI + ultrasound, six months apart. I live in Switzerland and here MRIs are quite easily given. I try and stay away from fatty food and sugar, the only difference with you is that my breasts are fatty and not dense. That having been said, the breast reduction caused scar tissue and fat necrosis so I suppose that equals dense breasts. I know I have 2x chance of getting BC, I'm not so worried about it, but I'm doing everything I can in case I do get it, to get it caught early.  I also get 2* week lymphatic massages (30 min per time) done by specialized therapist (a fantastic American lady). It activates the circulation and it feels good. Apparently, it's good for FB, but that's just my internet research that has said that. Nipple discharge is normal (if bilateral) and common with fibrocystic breasts. What I am wondering, if there's a link between hysterectomy and FB. If you want to PM me, do not hesitate. Best regards, alicki

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2014 08:30AM alicki wrote: hello, Ah you re the one! Mine was done by a plastic surgeon but an onc was in the background and due to my insistence, EVERYRHING removed was sent to pathology and ANALYSED. All came back fibrocystic which explained what was going on.  Let's take this from a logical point of view, if you cut stuff off, cancer can't grow there although it can grow elsewhere. Moreover, screening becomes easier. I'm monitored both here and in the UK. UK onc is one of the top five in the country and I trust him. There are also cultural differences between Europe and US. Here mascetomy for DCIS is uncommon and my onc here keeps saying that studies shows that life expentency is no different between lumpectomy and mascetomy. I don't know personnally. To my horror, I read that someone on the boards had a tumor come back after mascetomy on surgical scar.  IN the US, and correct me if I'm mistaken, you can get a mammography done twice a year or have many views done Here it's considered as a health risk and no way they will do it, they prefer to do an MRI instead or ultrasound. So BC care is also determined by culture practices.  Anyways, our experience is interesting. I think in addition exercise and healthy food can make a difference. I don't have atypical cells ...yet at least.  Monitoring provides reassurance and after that you just get on with life and hope for the best. Best Alicki

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2013 03:39AM alicki wrote: Hello, THis could be anything but given you're still in pain, swelling and dimples, I would get hold of and IBC specialist. NOT SAYING YOU HAVE THAT, i'm not a doc. And if you live anywhere near the MD anderson cancer center, they have an IBC clinic. Mastitis can clear up on it's own (mine did) but it took 5 weeks of intense pain (I was screaming in pain) and I was looking into IBC. I have had 3 MRIS, 1 Pet scan, ultrasounds and 4 biopsies. NOthing showed it aside inflammation, so I think I am reasonably safe. My breast grew with the mastitis because it clogged the ducts and lymphatic channels. <then it stopped growing in size. I am about to have a breast reduction. Skin is still funny now and still have pinholes but no evidence of C. Ultrasounds and mammos aren't good for this sort of thing. Biopsies and MRIs will give you a better picture. I don't know how insurance works in your country, but try asking the ladies on the IBC forum from the US. They will probably be able to help you Alicki
